segment.source: Administer security policy settings (Windows 10)
segment.target: Administer security policy settings (Windows 10)

segment.source: This article discusses different methods to administer security policy settings on a local device or throughout a small- or medium-sized organization.
segment.target: This article discusses different methods to administer security policy settings on a local device or throughout a small- or medium-sized organization.

segment.source: Administer security policy settings
segment.target: Administer security policy settings

segment.source: Applies to
segment.target: Applies to

segment.source: Windows 10
segment.target: Windows 10

segment.source: This article discusses different methods to administer security policy settings on a local device or throughout a small- or medium-sized organization.
segment.target: This article discusses different methods to administer security policy settings on a local device or throughout a small- or medium-sized organization.

segment.source: Security policy settings should be used as part of your overall security implementation to help secure domain controllers, servers, client devices, and other resources in your organization.
segment.target: Security policy settings should be used as part of your overall security implementation to help secure domain controllers, servers, client devices, and other resources in your organization.

segment.source: Security settings policies are rules that you can configure on a device, or multiple devices, for the purpose of protecting resources on a device or network.
segment.target: Security settings policies are rules that you can configure on a device, or multiple devices, for the purpose of protecting resources on a device or network.

segment.source: The Security Settings extension of the Local Group Policy Editor snap-in (Gpedit.msc) allows you to define security configurations as part of a Group Policy Object (GPO).
segment.target: The Security Settings extension of the Local Group Policy Editor snap-in (Gpedit.msc) allows you to define security configurations as part of a Group Policy Object (GPO).

segment.source: The GPOs are linked to Active Directory containers such as sites, domains, and organizational units, and they enable administrators to manage security settings for multiple computers from any device joined to the domain.
segment.target: The GPOs are linked to Active Directory containers such as sites, domains, and organizational units, and they enable administrators to manage security settings for multiple computers from any device joined to the domain.

segment.source: Security settings can control:
segment.target: Security settings can control:

segment.source: User authentication to a network or device.
segment.target: User authentication to a network or device.

segment.source: The resources that users are permitted to access.
segment.target: The resources that users are permitted to access.

segment.source: Whether to record a user’s or group’s actions in the event log.
segment.target: Whether to record a user’s or group’s actions in the event log.

segment.source: Membership in a group.
segment.target: Membership in a group.

segment.source: For info about each setting, including descriptions, default settings, and management and security considerations, see Security policy settings reference.
segment.target: For info about each setting, including descriptions, default settings, and management and security considerations, see Security policy settings reference.

segment.source: To manage security configurations for multiple computers, you can use one of the following options:
segment.target: To manage security configurations for multiple computers, you can use one of the following options:

segment.source: Edit specific security settings in a GPO.
segment.target: Edit specific security settings in a GPO.

segment.source: Use the Security Templates snap-in to create a security template that contains the security policies you want to apply, and then import the security template into a Group Policy Object.
segment.target: Use the Security Templates snap-in to create a security template that contains the security policies you want to apply, and then import the security template into a Group Policy Object.

segment.source: A security template is a file that represents a security configuration, and it can be imported to a GPO, or applied to a local device, or it can be used to analyze security.
segment.target: A security template is a file that represents a security configuration, and it can be imported to a GPO, or applied to a local device, or it can be used to analyze security.

segment.source: What’s changed in how settings are administered?
segment.target: What’s changed in how settings are administered?

segment.source: Over time, new ways to manage security policy settings have been introduced, which include new operating system features and the addition of new settings.
segment.target: Over time, new ways to manage security policy settings have been introduced, which include new operating system features and the addition of new settings.

segment.source: The following table lists different means by which security policy settings can be administered.
segment.target: The following table lists different means by which security policy settings can be administered.

segment.source: Tool or feature
segment.target: Tool or feature

segment.source: Description and use
segment.target: Description and use

segment.source: Security Policy snap-in
segment.target: Security Policy snap-in

segment.source: Secpol.msc
segment.target: Secpol.msc

segment.source: MMC snap-in designed to manage only security policy settings.
segment.target: MMC snap-in designed to manage only security policy settings.

segment.source: Security editor command line tool
segment.target: Security editor command line tool

segment.source: Secedit.exe
segment.target: Secedit.exe

segment.source: Configures and analyzes system security by comparing your current configuration to specified security templates.
segment.target: Configures and analyzes system security by comparing your current configuration to specified security templates.

segment.source: Security Compliance Manager
segment.target: Security Compliance Manager

segment.source: Tool download
segment.target: Tool download

segment.source: A Solution Accelerator that helps you plan, deploy, operate, and manage your security baselines for Windows client and server operating systems, and Microsoft applications.
segment.target: A Solution Accelerator that helps you plan, deploy, operate, and manage your security baselines for Windows client and server operating systems, and Microsoft applications.

segment.source: Security Configuration Wizard
segment.target: Security Configuration Wizard

segment.source: Scw.exe
segment.target: Scw.exe

segment.source: SCW is a role-based tool available on servers only: You can use it to create a policy that enables services, firewall rules, and settings that are required for a selected server to perform specific roles.
segment.target: SCW is a role-based tool available on servers only: You can use it to create a policy that enables services, firewall rules, and settings that are required for a selected server to perform specific roles.

segment.source: Security Configuration Manager tool
segment.target: Security Configuration Manager tool

segment.source: This tool set allows you to create, apply, and edit the security for your local device, organizational unit, or domain.
segment.target: This tool set allows you to create, apply, and edit the security for your local device, organizational unit, or domain.

segment.source: Group Policy
segment.target: Group Policy

segment.source: Gpmc.msc and Gpedit.msc
segment.target: Gpmc.msc and Gpedit.msc

segment.source: The Group Policy Management Console uses the Group Policy Object editor to expose the local Security options, which can then be incorporated into Group Policy Objects for distribution throughout the domain.
segment.target: The Group Policy Management Console uses the Group Policy Object editor to expose the local Security options, which can then be incorporated into Group Policy Objects for distribution throughout the domain.

segment.source: The Local Group Policy Editor performs similar functions on the local device.
segment.target: The Local Group Policy Editor performs similar functions on the local device.

segment.source: Software Restriction Policies
segment.target: Software Restriction Policies

segment.source: See Administer Software Restriction Policies.
segment.target: See Administer Software Restriction Policies.

segment.source: Gpedit.msc
segment.target: Gpedit.msc

segment.source: Software Restriction Policies (SRP) is a Group Policy-based feature that identifies software programs running on computers in a domain, and it controls the ability of those programs to run.
segment.target: Software Restriction Policies (SRP) is a Group Policy-based feature that identifies software programs running on computers in a domain, and it controls the ability of those programs to run.

segment.source: AppLocker
segment.target: AppLocker

segment.source: See Administer AppLocker.
segment.target: See Administer AppLocker.

segment.source: Gpedit.msc
segment.target: Gpedit.msc

segment.source: Prevents malicious software (malware) and unsupported applications from affecting computers in your environment, and it prevents users in your organization from installing and using unauthorized applications.
segment.target: Prevents malicious software (malware) and unsupported applications from affecting computers in your environment, and it prevents users in your organization from installing and using unauthorized applications.

segment.source: Using the Local Security Policy snap-in
segment.target: Using the Local Security Policy snap-in

segment.source: The Local Security Policy snap-in (Secpol.msc) restricts the view of local policy objects to the following policies and features:
segment.target: The Local Security Policy snap-in (Secpol.msc) restricts the view of local policy objects to the following policies and features:

segment.source: Account Policies
segment.target: Account Policies

segment.source: Local Policies
segment.target: Local Policies

segment.source: Windows Firewall with Advanced Security
segment.target: Windows Firewall with Advanced Security

segment.source: Network List Manager Policies
segment.target: Network List Manager Policies

segment.source: Public Key Policies
segment.target: Public Key Policies

segment.source: Software Restriction Policies
segment.target: Software Restriction Policies

segment.source: Application Control Policies
segment.target: Application Control Policies

segment.source: IP Security Policies on Local Computer
segment.target: IP Security Policies on Local Computer

segment.source: Advanced Audit Policy Configuration
segment.target: Advanced Audit Policy Configuration

segment.source: Policies set locally might be overwritten if the computer is joined to the domain.
segment.target: Policies set locally might be overwritten if the computer is joined to the domain.

segment.source: The Local Security Policy snap-in is part of the Security Configuration Manager tool set.
segment.target: The Local Security Policy snap-in is part of the Security Configuration Manager tool set.

segment.source: For info about other tools in this tool set, see Working with the Security Configuration Manager in this topic.
segment.target: For info about other tools in this tool set, see Working with the Security Configuration Manager in this topic.

segment.source: Using the secedit command-line tool
segment.target: Using the secedit command-line tool

segment.source: The secedit command-line tool works with security templates and provides six primary functions:
segment.target: The secedit command-line tool works with security templates and provides six primary functions:

segment.source: The Configure parameter helps you resolve security discrepancies between devices by applying the correct security template to the errant server.
segment.target: The Configure parameter helps you resolve security discrepancies between devices by applying the correct security template to the errant server.

segment.source: The Analyze parameter compares the server’s security configuration with the selected template.
segment.target: The Analyze parameter compares the server’s security configuration with the selected template.

segment.source: The Import parameter allows you to create a database from an existing template.
segment.target: The Import parameter allows you to create a database from an existing template.

segment.source: The Security Configuration and Analysis tool does this also.
segment.target: The Security Configuration and Analysis tool does this also.

segment.source: The Export parameter allows you to export the settings from a database into a security settings template.
segment.target: The Export parameter allows you to export the settings from a database into a security settings template.

segment.source: The Validate parameter allows you to validate the syntax of each or any lines of text that you created or added to a security template.
segment.target: The Validate parameter allows you to validate the syntax of each or any lines of text that you created or added to a security template.

segment.source: This ensures that if the template fails to apply syntax, the template will not be the issue.
segment.target: This ensures that if the template fails to apply syntax, the template will not be the issue.

segment.source: The Generate Rollback parameter saves the server’s current security settings into a security template so it can be used to restore most of the server’s security settings to a known state.
segment.target: The Generate Rollback parameter saves the server’s current security settings into a security template so it can be used to restore most of the server’s security settings to a known state.

segment.source: The exceptions are that, when applied, the rollback template will not change access control list entries on files or registry entries that were changed by the most recently applied template.
segment.target: The exceptions are that, when applied, the rollback template will not change access control list entries on files or registry entries that were changed by the most recently applied template.

segment.source: Using the Security Compliance Manager
segment.target: Using the Security Compliance Manager

segment.source: The Security Compliance Manager is a downloadable tool that helps you plan, deploy, operate, and manage your security baselines for Windows client and server operating systems, and for Microsoft applications.
segment.target: The Security Compliance Manager is a downloadable tool that helps you plan, deploy, operate, and manage your security baselines for Windows client and server operating systems, and for Microsoft applications.

segment.source: It contains a complete database of recommended security settings, methods to customize your baselines, and the option to implement those settings in multiple formats—including XLS, GPOs, Desired Configuration Management (DCM) packs, or Security Content Automation Protocol (SCAP).
segment.target: It contains a complete database of recommended security settings, methods to customize your baselines, and the option to implement those settings in multiple formats—including XLS, GPOs, Desired Configuration Management (DCM) packs, or Security Content Automation Protocol (SCAP).

segment.source: The Security Compliance Manager is used to export the baselines to your environment to automate the security baseline deployment and compliance verification process.
segment.target: The Security Compliance Manager is used to export the baselines to your environment to automate the security baseline deployment and compliance verification process.

segment.source: To administer security policies by using the Security Compliance Manager
segment.target: To administer security policies by using the Security Compliance Manager

segment.source: Download the most recent version.
segment.target: Download the most recent version.

segment.source: You can find out more info on the Microsoft Security Guidance blog.
segment.target: You can find out more info on the Microsoft Security Guidance blog.

segment.source: Read the relevant security baseline documentation that is included in this tool.
segment.target: Read the relevant security baseline documentation that is included in this tool.

segment.source: Download and import the relevant security baselines.
segment.target: Download and import the relevant security baselines.

segment.source: The installation process steps you through baseline selection.
segment.target: The installation process steps you through baseline selection.

segment.source: Open the Help and follow instructions how to customize, compare, or merge your security baselines before deploying those baselines.
segment.target: Open the Help and follow instructions how to customize, compare, or merge your security baselines before deploying those baselines.

segment.source: Using the Security Configuration Wizard
segment.target: Using the Security Configuration Wizard

segment.source: The Security Configuration Wizard (SCW) guides you through the process of creating, editing, applying, or rolling back a security policy.
segment.target: The Security Configuration Wizard (SCW) guides you through the process of creating, editing, applying, or rolling back a security policy.

segment.source: A security policy that you create with SCW is an .xml file that, when applied, configures services, network security, specific registry values, and audit policy.
segment.target: A security policy that you create with SCW is an .xml file that, when applied, configures services, network security, specific registry values, and audit policy.

segment.source: SCW is a role-based tool: You can use it to create a policy that enables services, firewall rules, and settings that are required for a selected server to perform specific roles.
segment.target: SCW is a role-based tool: You can use it to create a policy that enables services, firewall rules, and settings that are required for a selected server to perform specific roles.

segment.source: For example, a server might be a file server, a print server, or a domain controller.
segment.target: For example, a server might be a file server, a print server, or a domain controller.

segment.source: The following are considerations for using SCW:
segment.target: The following are considerations for using SCW:

segment.source: SCW disables unnecessary services and provides Windows Firewall with Advanced Security support.
segment.target: SCW disables unnecessary services and provides Windows Firewall with Advanced Security support.

segment.source: Security policies that are created with SCW are not the same as security templates, which are files with an .inf extension.
segment.target: Security policies that are created with SCW are not the same as security templates, which are files with an .inf extension.

segment.source: Security templates contain more security settings than those that can be set with SCW.
segment.target: Security templates contain more security settings than those that can be set with SCW.

segment.source: However, it is possible to include a security template in an SCW security policy file.
segment.target: However, it is possible to include a security template in an SCW security policy file.

segment.source: You can deploy security policies that you create with SCW by using Group Policy.
segment.target: You can deploy security policies that you create with SCW by using Group Policy.

segment.source: SCW does not install or uninstall the features necessary for the server to perform a role.
segment.target: SCW does not install or uninstall the features necessary for the server to perform a role.

segment.source: You can install server role-specific features through Server Manager.
segment.target: You can install server role-specific features through Server Manager.

segment.source: SCW detects server role dependencies.
segment.target: SCW detects server role dependencies.

segment.source: If you select a server role, it automatically selects dependent server roles.
segment.target: If you select a server role, it automatically selects dependent server roles.

segment.source: All apps that use the IP protocol and ports must be running on the server when you run SCW.
segment.target: All apps that use the IP protocol and ports must be running on the server when you run SCW.

segment.source: In some cases, you must be connected to the Internet to use the links in the SCW help.
segment.target: In some cases, you must be connected to the Internet to use the links in the SCW help.

segment.source: Note The SCW is available only on Windows Server and only applicable to server installations.
segment.target: Note The SCW is available only on Windows Server and only applicable to server installations.

segment.source: The SCW can be accessed through Server Manager or by running scw.exe.
segment.target: The SCW can be accessed through Server Manager or by running scw.exe.

segment.source: The wizard steps you through server security configuration to:
segment.target: The wizard steps you through server security configuration to:

segment.source: Create a security policy that can be applied to any server on your network.
segment.target: Create a security policy that can be applied to any server on your network.

segment.source: Edit an existing security policy.
segment.target: Edit an existing security policy.

segment.source: Apply an existing security policy.
segment.target: Apply an existing security policy.

segment.source: Roll back the last applied security policy.
segment.target: Roll back the last applied security policy.

segment.source: The Security Policy Wizard configures services and network security based on the server’s role, as well as configures auditing and registry settings.
segment.target: The Security Policy Wizard configures services and network security based on the server’s role, as well as configures auditing and registry settings.

segment.source: For more information about SCW, including procedures, see Security Configuration Wizard.
segment.target: For more information about SCW, including procedures, see Security Configuration Wizard.

segment.source: Working with the Security Configuration Manager
segment.target: Working with the Security Configuration Manager

segment.source: The Security Configuration Manager tool set allows you to create, apply, and edit the security for your local device, organizational unit, or domain.
segment.target: The Security Configuration Manager tool set allows you to create, apply, and edit the security for your local device, organizational unit, or domain.

segment.source: For procedures on how to use the Security Configuration Manager, see Security Configuration Manager.
segment.target: For procedures on how to use the Security Configuration Manager, see Security Configuration Manager.

segment.source: The following table lists the features of the Security Configuration Manager.
segment.target: The following table lists the features of the Security Configuration Manager.

segment.source: Security Configuration Manager tools
segment.target: Security Configuration Manager tools

segment.source: Description
segment.target: Description

segment.source: Security Configuration and Analysis
segment.target: Security Configuration and Analysis

segment.source: Defines a security policy in a template.
segment.target: Defines a security policy in a template.

segment.source: These templates can be applied to Group Policy or to your local computer.
segment.target: These templates can be applied to Group Policy or to your local computer.

segment.source: Security templates
segment.target: Security templates

segment.source: Defines a security policy in a template.
segment.target: Defines a security policy in a template.

segment.source: These templates can be applied to Group Policy or to your local computer.
segment.target: These templates can be applied to Group Policy or to your local computer.

segment.source: Security Settings extension to Group Policy
segment.target: Security Settings extension to Group Policy

segment.source: Edits individual security settings on a domain, site, or organizational unit.
segment.target: Edits individual security settings on a domain, site, or organizational unit.

segment.source: Local Security Policy
segment.target: Local Security Policy

segment.source: Edits individual security settings on your local computer.
segment.target: Edits individual security settings on your local computer.

segment.source: Secedit
segment.target: Secedit

segment.source: Automates security configuration tasks at a command prompt.
segment.target: Automates security configuration tasks at a command prompt.

segment.source: Security Configuration and Analysis
segment.target: Security Configuration and Analysis

segment.source: Security Configuration and Analysis is an MMC snap-in for analyzing and configuring local system security.
segment.target: Security Configuration and Analysis is an MMC snap-in for analyzing and configuring local system security.

segment.source: Security analysis
segment.target: Security analysis

segment.source: The state of the operating system and apps on a device is dynamic.
segment.target: The state of the operating system and apps on a device is dynamic.

segment.source: For example, you may need to temporarily change security levels so that you can immediately resolve an administration or network issue.
segment.target: For example, you may need to temporarily change security levels so that you can immediately resolve an administration or network issue.

segment.source: However, this change can often go unreversed.
segment.target: However, this change can often go unreversed.

segment.source: This means that a computer may no longer meet the requirements for enterprise security.
segment.target: This means that a computer may no longer meet the requirements for enterprise security.

segment.source: Regular analysis enables you to track and ensure an adequate level of security on each computer as part of an enterprise risk management program.
segment.target: Regular analysis enables you to track and ensure an adequate level of security on each computer as part of an enterprise risk management program.

segment.source: You can tune the security levels and, most importantly, detect any security flaws that may occur in the system over time.
segment.target: You can tune the security levels and, most importantly, detect any security flaws that may occur in the system over time.

segment.source: Security Configuration and Analysis enables you to quickly review security analysis results.
segment.target: Security Configuration and Analysis enables you to quickly review security analysis results.

segment.source: It presents recommendations alongside of current system settings and uses visual flags or remarks to highlight any areas where the current settings do not match the proposed level of security.
segment.target: It presents recommendations alongside of current system settings and uses visual flags or remarks to highlight any areas where the current settings do not match the proposed level of security.

segment.source: Security Configuration and Analysis also offers the ability to resolve any discrepancies that analysis reveals.
segment.target: Security Configuration and Analysis also offers the ability to resolve any discrepancies that analysis reveals.

segment.source: Security configuration
segment.target: Security configuration

segment.source: Security Configuration and Analysis can also be used to directly configure local system security.
segment.target: Security Configuration and Analysis can also be used to directly configure local system security.

segment.source: Through its use of personal databases, you can import security templates that have been created with Security Templates and apply these templates to the local computer.
segment.target: Through its use of personal databases, you can import security templates that have been created with Security Templates and apply these templates to the local computer.

segment.source: This immediately configures the system security with the levels specified in the template.
segment.target: This immediately configures the system security with the levels specified in the template.

segment.source: Security templates
segment.target: Security templates

segment.source: With the Security Templates snap-in for Microsoft Management Console, you can create a security policy for your device or for your network.
segment.target: With the Security Templates snap-in for Microsoft Management Console, you can create a security policy for your device or for your network.

segment.source: It is a single point of entry where the full range of system security can be taken into account.
segment.target: It is a single point of entry where the full range of system security can be taken into account.

segment.source: The Security Templates snap-in does not introduce new security parameters, it simply organizes all existing security attributes into one place to ease security administration.
segment.target: The Security Templates snap-in does not introduce new security parameters, it simply organizes all existing security attributes into one place to ease security administration.

segment.source: Importing a security template to a Group Policy Object eases domain administration by configuring security for a domain or organizational unit at once.
segment.target: Importing a security template to a Group Policy Object eases domain administration by configuring security for a domain or organizational unit at once.

segment.source: To apply a security template to your local device, you can use Security Configuration and Analysis or the secedit command-line tool.
segment.target: To apply a security template to your local device, you can use Security Configuration and Analysis or the secedit command-line tool.

segment.source: Security templates can be used to define:
segment.target: Security templates can be used to define:

segment.source: Account Policies
segment.target: Account Policies

segment.source: Password Policy
segment.target: Password Policy

segment.source: Account Lockout Policy
segment.target: Account Lockout Policy

segment.source: Kerberos Policy
segment.target: Kerberos Policy

segment.source: Local Policies
segment.target: Local Policies

segment.source: Audit Policy
segment.target: Audit Policy

segment.source: User Rights Assignment
segment.target: User Rights Assignment

segment.source: Security Options
segment.target: Security Options

segment.source: Event Log: Application, system, and security Event Log settings
segment.target: Event Log: Application, system, and security Event Log settings

segment.source: Restricted Groups: Membership of security-sensitive groups
segment.target: Restricted Groups: Membership of security-sensitive groups

segment.source: System Services: Startup and permissions for system services
segment.target: System Services: Startup and permissions for system services

segment.source: Registry: Permissions for registry keys
segment.target: Registry: Permissions for registry keys

segment.source: File System: Permissions for folders and files
segment.target: File System: Permissions for folders and files

segment.source: Each template is saved as a text-based .inf file.
segment.target: Each template is saved as a text-based .inf file.

segment.source: This enables you to copy, paste, import, or export some or all of the template attributes.
segment.target: This enables you to copy, paste, import, or export some or all of the template attributes.

segment.source: With the exceptions of Internet Protocol security and public key policies, all security attributes can be contained in a security template.
segment.target: With the exceptions of Internet Protocol security and public key policies, all security attributes can be contained in a security template.

segment.source: Security settings extension to Group Policy
segment.target: Security settings extension to Group Policy

segment.source: Organizational units, domains, and sites are linked to Group Policy Objects.
segment.target: Organizational units, domains, and sites are linked to Group Policy Objects.

segment.source: The security settings tool allows you change the security configuration of the Group Policy Object, in turn, affecting multiple computers.
segment.target: The security settings tool allows you change the security configuration of the Group Policy Object, in turn, affecting multiple computers.

segment.source: With security settings, you can modify the security settings of many devices, depending on the Group Policy Object you modify, from just one device joined to a domain.
segment.target: With security settings, you can modify the security settings of many devices, depending on the Group Policy Object you modify, from just one device joined to a domain.

segment.source: Security settings or security policies are rules that are configured on a device or multiple device for protecting resources on a device or network.
segment.target: Security settings or security policies are rules that are configured on a device or multiple device for protecting resources on a device or network.

segment.source: Security settings can control:
segment.target: Security settings can control:

segment.source: How users are authenticated to a network or device
segment.target: How users are authenticated to a network or device

segment.source: What resources users are authorized to use.
segment.target: What resources users are authorized to use.

segment.source: Whether or not a user's or group's actions are recorded in the event log.
segment.target: Whether or not a user's or group's actions are recorded in the event log.

segment.source: Group membership.
segment.target: Group membership.

segment.source: You can change the security configuration on multiple computers in two ways:
segment.target: You can change the security configuration on multiple computers in two ways:

segment.source: Create a security policy by using a security template with Security Templates, and then import the template through security settings to a Group Policy Object.
segment.target: Create a security policy by using a security template with Security Templates, and then import the template through security settings to a Group Policy Object.

segment.source: Change a few select settings with security settings.
segment.target: Change a few select settings with security settings.

segment.source: Local Security Policy
segment.target: Local Security Policy

segment.source: A security policy is a combination of security settings that affect the security on a device.
segment.target: A security policy is a combination of security settings that affect the security on a device.

segment.source: You can use your local security policy to edit account policies and local policies on your local device
segment.target: You can use your local security policy to edit account policies and local policies on your local device

segment.source: With the local security policy, you can control:
segment.target: With the local security policy, you can control:

segment.source: Who accesses your device.
segment.target: Who accesses your device.

segment.source: What resources users are authorized to use on your device.
segment.target: What resources users are authorized to use on your device.

segment.source: Whether or not a user’s or group's actions are recorded in the event log.
segment.target: Whether or not a user’s or group's actions are recorded in the event log.

segment.source: If your local device is joined to a domain, you are subject to obtaining a security policy from the domain's policy or from the policy of any organizational unit that you are a member of.
segment.target: If your local device is joined to a domain, you are subject to obtaining a security policy from the domain's policy or from the policy of any organizational unit that you are a member of.

segment.source: If you are getting a policy from more than one source, conflicts are resolved in the following order of precedence.
segment.target: If you are getting a policy from more than one source, conflicts are resolved in the following order of precedence.

segment.source: Organizational unit policy
segment.target: Organizational unit policy

segment.source: Domain policy
segment.target: Domain policy

segment.source: Site policy
segment.target: Site policy

segment.source: Local computer policy
segment.target: Local computer policy

segment.source: If you modify the security settings on your local device by using the local security policy, then you are directly modifying the settings on your device.
segment.target: If you modify the security settings on your local device by using the local security policy, then you are directly modifying the settings on your device.

segment.source: Therefore, the settings take effect immediately, but this may only be temporary.
segment.target: Therefore, the settings take effect immediately, but this may only be temporary.

segment.source: The settings will actually remain in effect on your local device until the next refresh of Group Policy security settings, when the security settings that are received from Group Policy will override your local settings wherever there are conflicts.
segment.target: The settings will actually remain in effect on your local device until the next refresh of Group Policy security settings, when the security settings that are received from Group Policy will override your local settings wherever there are conflicts.

segment.source: Using the Security Configuration Manager
segment.target: Using the Security Configuration Manager

segment.source: For procedures on how to use the Security Configuration Manager, see Security Configuration Manager How To.
segment.target: For procedures on how to use the Security Configuration Manager, see Security Configuration Manager How To.

segment.source: This section contains information in this topic about:
segment.target: This section contains information in this topic about:

segment.source: Applying security settings
segment.target: Applying security settings

segment.source: Importing and exporting security templates
segment.target: Importing and exporting security templates

segment.source: Analyzing security and viewing results
segment.target: Analyzing security and viewing results

segment.source: Resolving security discrepancies
segment.target: Resolving security discrepancies

segment.source: Automating security configuration tasks
segment.target: Automating security configuration tasks

segment.source: Applying security settings
segment.target: Applying security settings

segment.source: Once you have edited the security settings, the settings are refreshed on the computers in the organizational unit linked to your Group Policy Object:
segment.target: Once you have edited the security settings, the settings are refreshed on the computers in the organizational unit linked to your Group Policy Object:

segment.source: When a device is restarted, the settings on that device will be refreshed.
segment.target: When a device is restarted, the settings on that device will be refreshed.

segment.source: To force a device to refresh its security settings as well as all Group Policy settings, use gpupdate.exe.
segment.target: To force a device to refresh its security settings as well as all Group Policy settings, use gpupdate.exe.

segment.source: Precedence of a policy when more than one policy is applied to a computer
segment.target: Precedence of a policy when more than one policy is applied to a computer

segment.source: For security settings that are defined by more than one policy, the following order of precedence is observed:
segment.target: For security settings that are defined by more than one policy, the following order of precedence is observed:

segment.source: Organizational Unit Policy
segment.target: Organizational Unit Policy

segment.source: Domain Policy
segment.target: Domain Policy

segment.source: Site Policy
segment.target: Site Policy

segment.source: Local computer Policy
segment.target: Local computer Policy

segment.source: For example, a workstation that is joined to a domain will have its local security settings overridden by the domain policy wherever there is a conflict.
segment.target: For example, a workstation that is joined to a domain will have its local security settings overridden by the domain policy wherever there is a conflict.

segment.source: Likewise, if the same workstation is a member of an Organizational Unit, the settings applied from the Organizational Unit's policy will override both the domain and local settings.
segment.target: Likewise, if the same workstation is a member of an Organizational Unit, the settings applied from the Organizational Unit's policy will override both the domain and local settings.

segment.source: If the workstation is a member of more than one Organizational Unit, then the Organizational Unit that immediately contains the workstation has the highest order of precedence.
segment.target: If the workstation is a member of more than one Organizational Unit, then the Organizational Unit that immediately contains the workstation has the highest order of precedence.

segment.source: Note Use gpresult.exe to find out what policies are applied to a device and in what order.
segment.target: Note Use gpresult.exe to find out what policies are applied to a device and in what order.

segment.source: For domain accounts, there can be only one account policy that includes password policies, account lockout policies, and Kerberos policies.
segment.target: For domain accounts, there can be only one account policy that includes password policies, account lockout policies, and Kerberos policies.

segment.source: Persistence in security settings
segment.target: Persistence in security settings

segment.source: Security settings may still persist even if a setting is no longer defined in the policy that originally applied it.
segment.target: Security settings may still persist even if a setting is no longer defined in the policy that originally applied it.

segment.source: Persistence in security settings occurs when:
segment.target: Persistence in security settings occurs when:

segment.source: The setting has not been previously defined for the device.
segment.target: The setting has not been previously defined for the device.

segment.source: The setting is for a registry object.
segment.target: The setting is for a registry object.

segment.source: The setting is for a file system object.
segment.target: The setting is for a file system object.

segment.source: All settings applied through local policy or a Group Policy Object are stored in a local database on your device.
segment.target: All settings applied through local policy or a Group Policy Object are stored in a local database on your device.

segment.source: Whenever a security setting is modified, the computer saves the security setting value to the local database, which retains a history of all the settings that have been applied to the device.
segment.target: Whenever a security setting is modified, the computer saves the security setting value to the local database, which retains a history of all the settings that have been applied to the device.

segment.source: If a policy first defines a security setting and then no longer defines that setting, then the setting takes on the previous value in the database.
segment.target: If a policy first defines a security setting and then no longer defines that setting, then the setting takes on the previous value in the database.

segment.source: If a previous value does not exist in the database, then the setting does not revert to anything and remains defined as is.
segment.target: If a previous value does not exist in the database, then the setting does not revert to anything and remains defined as is.

segment.source: This behavior is sometimes called "tattooing."
segment.target: This behavior is sometimes called "tattooing."

segment.source: Registry and file settings will maintain the values applied through policy until that setting is set to other values.
segment.target: Registry and file settings will maintain the values applied through policy until that setting is set to other values.

segment.source: Filtering security settings based on group membership
segment.target: Filtering security settings based on group membership

segment.source: You can also decide what users or groups will or will not have a Group Policy Object applied to them regardless of what computer they have logged onto by denying them either the Apply Group Policy or Read permission on that Group Policy Object.
segment.target: You can also decide what users or groups will or will not have a Group Policy Object applied to them regardless of what computer they have logged onto by denying them either the Apply Group Policy or Read permission on that Group Policy Object.

segment.source: Both of these permissions are needed to apply Group Policy.
segment.target: Both of these permissions are needed to apply Group Policy.

segment.source: Importing and exporting security templates
segment.target: Importing and exporting security templates

segment.source: Security Configuration and Analysis provides the ability to import and export security templates into or from a database.
segment.target: Security Configuration and Analysis provides the ability to import and export security templates into or from a database.

segment.source: If you have made any changes to the analysis database, you can save those settings by exporting them into a template.
segment.target: If you have made any changes to the analysis database, you can save those settings by exporting them into a template.

segment.source: The export feature provides the ability to save the analysis database settings as a new template file.
segment.target: The export feature provides the ability to save the analysis database settings as a new template file.

segment.source: This template file can then be used to analyze or configure a system, or it can be imported to a Group Policy Object.
segment.target: This template file can then be used to analyze or configure a system, or it can be imported to a Group Policy Object.

segment.source: Analyzing security and viewing results
segment.target: Analyzing security and viewing results

segment.source: Security Configuration and Analysis performs security analysis by comparing the current state of system security against an analysis database.
segment.target: Security Configuration and Analysis performs security analysis by comparing the current state of system security against an analysis database.

segment.source: During creation, the analysis database uses at least one security template.
segment.target: During creation, the analysis database uses at least one security template.

segment.source: If you choose to import more than one security template, the database will merge the various templates and create one composite template.
segment.target: If you choose to import more than one security template, the database will merge the various templates and create one composite template.

segment.source: It resolves conflicts in order of import; the last template that is imported takes precedence.
segment.target: It resolves conflicts in order of import; the last template that is imported takes precedence.

segment.source: Security Configuration and Analysis displays the analysis results by security area, using visual flags to indicate problems.
segment.target: Security Configuration and Analysis displays the analysis results by security area, using visual flags to indicate problems.

segment.source: It displays the current system and base configuration settings for each security attribute in the security areas.
segment.target: It displays the current system and base configuration settings for each security attribute in the security areas.

segment.source: To change the analysis database settings, right-click the entry, and then click Properties.
segment.target: To change the analysis database settings, right-click the entry, and then click Properties.

segment.source: Visual flag
segment.target: Visual flag

segment.source: Meaning
segment.target: Meaning

segment.source: Red X
segment.target: Red X

segment.source: The entry is defined in the analysis database and on the system, but the security setting values do not match.
segment.target: The entry is defined in the analysis database and on the system, but the security setting values do not match.

segment.source: Green check mark
segment.target: Green check mark

segment.source: The entry is defined in the analysis database and on the system and the setting values match.
segment.target: The entry is defined in the analysis database and on the system and the setting values match.

segment.source: Question mark
segment.target: Question mark

segment.source: The entry is not defined in the analysis database and, therefore, was not analyzed.
segment.target: The entry is not defined in the analysis database and, therefore, was not analyzed.

segment.source: If an entry is not analyzed, it may be that it was not defined in the analysis database or that the user who is running the analysis may not have sufficient permission to perform analysis on a specific object or area.
segment.target: If an entry is not analyzed, it may be that it was not defined in the analysis database or that the user who is running the analysis may not have sufficient permission to perform analysis on a specific object or area.

segment.source: Exclamation point
segment.target: Exclamation point

segment.source: This item is defined in the analysis database, but does not exist on the actual system.
segment.target: This item is defined in the analysis database, but does not exist on the actual system.

segment.source: For example, there may be a restricted group that is defined in the analysis database but does not actually exist on the analyzed system.
segment.target: For example, there may be a restricted group that is defined in the analysis database but does not actually exist on the analyzed system.

segment.source: No highlight
segment.target: No highlight

segment.source: The item is not defined in the analysis database or on the system.
segment.target: The item is not defined in the analysis database or on the system.

segment.source: If you choose to accept the current settings, the corresponding value in the base configuration is modified to match them.
segment.target: If you choose to accept the current settings, the corresponding value in the base configuration is modified to match them.

segment.source: If you change the system setting to match the base configuration, the change will be reflected when you configure the system with Security Configuration and Analysis.
segment.target: If you change the system setting to match the base configuration, the change will be reflected when you configure the system with Security Configuration and Analysis.

segment.source: To avoid continued flagging of settings that you have investigated and determined to be reasonable, you can modify the base configuration.
segment.target: To avoid continued flagging of settings that you have investigated and determined to be reasonable, you can modify the base configuration.

segment.source: The changes are made to a copy of the template.
segment.target: The changes are made to a copy of the template.

segment.source: Resolving security discrepancies
segment.target: Resolving security discrepancies

segment.source: You can resolve discrepancies between analysis database and system settings by:
segment.target: You can resolve discrepancies between analysis database and system settings by:

segment.source: Accepting or changing some or all of the values that are flagged or not included in the configuration, if you determine that the local system security levels are valid due to the context (or role) of that computer.
segment.target: Accepting or changing some or all of the values that are flagged or not included in the configuration, if you determine that the local system security levels are valid due to the context (or role) of that computer.

segment.source: These attribute values are then updated in the database and applied to the system when you click Configure Computer Now.
segment.target: These attribute values are then updated in the database and applied to the system when you click Configure Computer Now.

segment.source: Configuring the system to the analysis database values, if you determine the system is not in compliance with valid security levels.
segment.target: Configuring the system to the analysis database values, if you determine the system is not in compliance with valid security levels.

segment.source: Importing a more appropriate template for the role of that computer into the database as the new base configuration and applying it to the system.
segment.target: Importing a more appropriate template for the role of that computer into the database as the new base configuration and applying it to the system.

segment.source: Changes to the analysis database are made to the stored template in the database, not to the security template file.
segment.target: Changes to the analysis database are made to the stored template in the database, not to the security template file.

segment.source: The security template file will only be modified if you either return to Security Templates and edit that template or export the stored configuration to the same template file.
segment.target: The security template file will only be modified if you either return to Security Templates and edit that template or export the stored configuration to the same template file.

segment.source: You should use Configure Computer Now only to modify security areas not affected by Group Policy settings, such as security on local files and folders, registry keys, and system services.
segment.target: You should use Configure Computer Now only to modify security areas not affected by Group Policy settings, such as security on local files and folders, registry keys, and system services.

segment.source: Otherwise, when the Group Policy settings are applied, it will take precedence over local settings—such as account policies.
segment.target: Otherwise, when the Group Policy settings are applied, it will take precedence over local settings—such as account policies.

segment.source: In general, do not use Configure Computer Now when you are analyzing security for domain-based clients, since you will have to configure each client individually.
segment.target: In general, do not use Configure Computer Now when you are analyzing security for domain-based clients, since you will have to configure each client individually.

segment.source: In this case, you should return to Security Templates, modify the template, and reapply it to the appropriate Group Policy Object.
segment.target: In this case, you should return to Security Templates, modify the template, and reapply it to the appropriate Group Policy Object.

segment.source: Automating security configuration tasks
segment.target: Automating security configuration tasks

segment.source: By calling the secedit.exe tool at a command prompt from a batch file or automatic task scheduler, you can use it to automatically create and apply templates, and analyze system security.
segment.target: By calling the secedit.exe tool at a command prompt from a batch file or automatic task scheduler, you can use it to automatically create and apply templates, and analyze system security.

segment.source: You can also run it dynamically from a command prompt.
segment.target: You can also run it dynamically from a command prompt.

segment.source: Secedit.exe is useful when you have multiple devices on which security must be analyzed or configured, and you need to perform these tasks during off-hours.
segment.target: Secedit.exe is useful when you have multiple devices on which security must be analyzed or configured, and you need to perform these tasks during off-hours.

segment.source: Working with Group Policy tools
segment.target: Working with Group Policy tools

segment.source: Group Policy is an infrastructure that allows you to specify managed configurations for users and computers through Group Policy settings and Group Policy Preferences.
segment.target: Group Policy is an infrastructure that allows you to specify managed configurations for users and computers through Group Policy settings and Group Policy Preferences.

segment.source: For Group Policy settings that affect only a local device or user, you can use the Local Group Policy Editor.
segment.target: For Group Policy settings that affect only a local device or user, you can use the Local Group Policy Editor.

segment.source: You can manage Group Policy settings and Group Policy Preferences in an Active Directory Domain Services (AD DS) environment through the Group Policy Management Console (GPMC).
segment.target: You can manage Group Policy settings and Group Policy Preferences in an Active Directory Domain Services (AD DS) environment through the Group Policy Management Console (GPMC).

segment.source: Group Policy management tools also are included in the Remote Server Administration Tools pack to provide a way for you to administer Group Policy settings from your desktop.
segment.target: Group Policy management tools also are included in the Remote Server Administration Tools pack to provide a way for you to administer Group Policy settings from your desktop.
